member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.Surface
member.summary: A surface represents a linear area of display memory. A surface usually resides in the display memory of the display card, although surfaces can exist in system memory. Unless specifically instructed otherwise during the creation of the Surface object, DirectDraw will put the Surface object wherever the best performance can be achieved given the requested capabilities. Surface objects can take advantage of specialized processors on display cards, not only to perform certain tasks faster, but to perform some tasks in parallel with the system CPU.

member.summary: This surface contains alpha-only information.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.BackBuffer
member.summary: This surface is the back buffer of a surface flipping structure.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.Complex
member.summary: A complex surface is being described. A complex surface results in the creation of more than one surface. The additional surfaces are attached to the root surface. The complex surface can be destroyed only by destroying the root.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.Flip
member.summary: This surface is a part of a surface-flipping structure.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.FrontBuffer
member.summary: This surface is the front buffer of a surface-flipping structure.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.HardwareCodec
member.summary: This surface can have a stream decompressed to it by the hardware.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.LiveVideo
member.summary: This surface can receive live video.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.LocalVideoMemory
member.summary: This surface exists in true, local video memory, rather than nonlocal video memory. If this flag is specified, VideoMemory must be specified, as well. This flag cannot be used with the NonLocalVideoMemory flag.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.ModeX
member.summary: This surface is a 320200 or 320240 Mode X surface.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.NonLocalVideoMemory
member.summary: This surface exists in nonlocal video memory, rather than true, local video memory. If this flag is specified, VideoMemory flag must be specified, as well. This cannot be used with the LocalVideoMemory flag.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.OffScreenPlain
member.summary: This surface is any off-screen surface that is not an overlay, front-buffer, back-buffer, or alpha surface. It is used to identify plain surfaces.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.Overlay
member.summary: This surface is an overlay. It might or might not be directly visible, depending on whether it is currently being overlaid onto the primary surface.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.OwnGraphics
member.summary: This surface has a device context (DC) association for a long period of time.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.Palette
member.summary: This device driver allows unique DirectDrawPalette objects to be created and attached to this surface.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.PrimarySurface
member.summary: The surface is the primary surface. It represents what is currently visible.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.StandardVgaMode
member.summary: This surface is a standard VGA mode surface, and not a Mode X surface. This flag cannot be used in combination with the ModeX flag.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.StereoSurfaceLeft
member.summary: This surface is part of a stereo flipping chain.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.SystemMemory
member.summary: This surface memory was allocated in system memory.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.VideoMemory
member.summary: This surface exists in display memory.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.VideoPort
member.summary: This surface can receive data from a video port.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.Visible
member.summary: Changes made to this surface are immediately visible. It is always set for the primary surface, as well as for overlays while they are being overlaid and texture maps while they are being textured.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.SurfaceCaps.WriteAccessOnly
member.summary: Only write access is permitted to the surface. Read access from the surface can cause a general protection (GP) fault, and the read results from this surface would not be meaningful.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.Caps.AutoFlipOverlay
member.summary: The overlay can be automatically flipped to the next surface in the flipping chain each time that a video port VSYNC occurs, allowing the video port and the overlay to double-buffer the video without CPU overhead. This option is only valid when the surface is receiving data from a video port. If the video port data is noninterlaced or noninterleaved, it flips on every VSYNC. If the data is being interleaved in memory, it flips on every other VSYNC.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.Caps.OverlayHardwareDisplaysInterleavedVideo
member.summary: The overlay hardware can display each field of an interlaced video stream individually while it is interleaved in memory without causing any artifacts that might normally occur without special hardware support. This option is only valid when the surface is receiving data from a video port and the video is zoomed at least twice in the vertical direction.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.Caps.OverlayHardwareDisplaysNonInterleavedVideo
member.summary: The overlay hardware can display each field of an interlaced video stream individually while it is not interleaved in memory without causing any artifacts that might normally occur without special hardware support. This option is only valid when the surface is receiving data from a video port and the video is zoomed at least twice in the vertical direction.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.ColorControlObject.Brightness
member.summary: Luminance intensity, in IRE units times 100. The valid range is from 0 through 10,000. The default is 750, which translates to 7.5 IRE.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.ColorControlObject.ColorEnable
member.summary: Flag indicating whether color is used.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.ColorControlObject.Contrast
member.summary: Relative difference between higher and lower intensity luminance values in IRE units times 100. The valid range is from 0 through 20,000. The default value is 10,000 (100 IRE). Higher values of contrast cause darker luminance values to tend toward black and lighter luminance values to tend toward white. Lower values of contrast cause all luminance values to move toward the middle of the scale.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.ColorControlObject.Gamma
member.summary: Controls the amount of gamma correction applied to the luminance values. The valid range is from 1 through 500 gamma units, with a default of 1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.ColorControlObject.Hue
member.summary: Phase relationship of the chrominance components. Hue is specified in degrees, and the valid range is from 180 through 180, with a default of 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps
member.summary: Driver-specific alpha capabilities

member.name: M:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.ToString
member.summary: Obtains the String representation of this instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.DrawAlphaEdgeBlend
member.summary: Supports alpha blending around the edge of a source color-keyed surface. Used for draw operations.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.DrawAlphaPixels
member.summary: Supports alpha information in pixel format. The bit depth of alpha information in the pixel format can be 1, 2, 4, or 8. The alpha value becomes more opaque as the alpha value increases. Regardless of the depth of the alpha information, 0 is always the fully transparent value. Used for blit operations.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.DrawAlphaPixelsNegative
member.summary: Supports alpha information in pixel format. The bit depth of alpha information in the pixel format can be 1, 2, 4, or 8. The alpha value becomes more transparent as the alpha value increases. Regardless of the depth of the alpha information, 0 is always the fully opaque value. This flag can be used only if Alpha is set. Used for draw operations.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.DrawAlphaSurfaces
member.summary: Supports alpha-only surfaces. The bit depth of an alpha-only surface can be 1, 2, 4, or 8. The alpha value becomes more opaque as the alpha value increases. Regardless of the depth of the alpha information, 0 is always the fully transparent value. Used for blit operations.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.DrawAlphaSurfacesNegative
member.summary: Indicates that the alpha channel becomes more transparent as the alpha value increases. The depth of the alpha channel-data can be 1, 2, 4, or 8. Regardless of the depth of the alpha information, 0 is always the fully opaque value. This flag can be set only if Alpha has been set. Used for blit operations.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.OverlayAlphaEdgeBlend
member.summary: Supports alpha blending around the edge of a source color-keyed surface. Used for overlays.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.OverlayAlphaPixels
member.summary: Supports alpha information in pixel format. The bit depth of alpha information in pixel format can be 1, 2, 4, or 8. The alpha value becomes more opaque as the alpha value increases. Regardless of the depth of the alpha information, 0 is always the fully transparent value. Used for overlays.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.OverlayAlphaPixelsNegative
member.summary: Supports alpha information in pixel format. The bit depth of alpha information in pixel format can be 1, 2, 4, or 8. The alpha value becomes more transparent as the alpha value increases. Regardless of the depth of the alpha information, 0 is always the fully opaque value. This flag can be used only if Alpha has been set. Used for overlays.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.OverlayAlphaSurfaces
member.summary: Supports alpha-only surfaces. The bit depth of an alpha-only surface can be 1, 2, 4, or 8. The alpha value becomes more opaque as the alpha value increases. Regardless of the depth of the alpha information, 0 is always the fully transparent value. Used for overlays.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.FXAlphaCaps.OverlayAlphaSurfacesNegative
member.summary: Indicates that the alpha channel becomes more transparent as the alpha value increases. The depth of the alpha-channel data can be 1, 2, 4, or 8. Regardless of the depth of the alpha information, 0 is always the fully opaque value. This flag can be used only if Alpha has been set. Used for overlays.

member.summary: Uses arithmetic operations, rather than pixel-doubling techniques, to stretch and shrink surfaces during a blit operation. Occurs along the y-axis (vertically), and works only for integer stretching (1, 2, and so on).

member.summary: Driver can do surface-reconstruction filtering for warped blits.

member.name: P:Microsoft.DirectX.DirectDraw.PixelFormat.RgbToYuv
member.summary: The surface accepts RGB data and translates it during the write operation to YUV data. The format of the data to be written is contained in the pixel format structure. The Rgb flag is set.
